article.title: Im2Flow: Motion Hallucination from Static Images for Action Recognition

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the "inferred flow image" in Figure 1 represent?
choices: The actual optical flow computed from a video sequence.
A random pattern of motion vectors.
The predicted motion for the static image based on a learned motion prior from videos.
The ground-truth motion annotations provided by human labelers.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the role of the "skip connections" in the Im2Flow network architecture shown in Figure 2?
choices: They introduce non-linearity into the network, allowing it to learn complex mappings.
They directly connect the encoder and decoder at multiple levels, facilitating the flow of low-level information.
They act as a regularization mechanism, preventing overfitting during training.
They compute the motion content loss by comparing the activations of different network layers.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3 compares the dense optical flow prediction of different methods. What is the key advantage of the proposed Im2Flow method (c) over the approach of Walker et al. [77] (b)?
choices: Im2Flow produces flow maps with smoother and visually more appealing motion patterns.
Im2Flow can predict motion for a wider range of action categories.
Im2Flow generates more reliable and fine-grained predictions, capturing motion details at a finer level.
Im2Flow is computationally more efficient and requires less training data.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 4 showcases static images with different levels of "motion potential" as determined by the Im2Flow framework. What does a high motion potential score suggest about an image?
choices: The image depicts a fast-moving object.
The image contains a large number of objects.
The image is visually complex and contains a lot of texture.
The image is suggestive of coming events and implies a high likelihood of future motion.
